required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Robot-assisted Versus Laparoscopic Surgery for Mid/Low Rectal Cancer
clinical_study.official_title: Robot-assisted Versus Laparoscopic Surgery for Mid/Low Rectal Cancer (REAL): A Multicenter Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and oncological feasibility of robot-assisted surgery for mid/low rectal carcinoma compared with laparoscopic surgery.

detailed_description.textblock: Laparoscopic surgery as the treatment for colon cancer has been widely recognized. But its use for rectal cancer is still controversial. Previous trials have shown that although the long-term survival outcomes were similar, laparoscopic surgery did not reach the non-inferiority in terms of local tumor radical resection, compared with open surgery. Robotic techniques are considered to improve the quality of surgery with three-dimensional vision, stable camera platform and flexible robotic arms. Meta-analyses have shown that compared with laparoscopic surgery, robotic surgery could improve surgical quality in terms of open conversion, circumferential resection margin, postoperative complications, postoperative recovery, and quality of life, with similar long-term survival. However, these evidences mainly came from retrospective studies and small-scale randomized controlled trials with low quality. There still needs high-quality clinical trials to confirm the advantages of robotic surgery for rectal cancer.

primary_outcome.description: The proportion of patients with any cancer recurrence in the pelvic or perineal area

secondary_outcome.description: The proportion of patients with circumferential resection margin ≤ 1 mm from the tumor
The proportion of patients with any complications occurred within 30 days after surgery
Time from surgery to any recurrence, metastases or death
Time from making skin incision to suturing the incision during the surgery

secondary_outcome.measure: Rate of conversion to open surgery
secondary_outcome.description: The proportion of patients with the use of a laparotomy incision for any part of the TME procedure or lymph nodes dissection during the surgery
Blood loss will be measured according to the suction and the weight of wet gauze, and then minus the irrigation.

The proximal/distal resection margin will be reported as "positive" or "negative" to define whether tumor is radically resected. It will be reported according to the post-operative pathology. Details are based on NCCN and Chinese guidelines for colorectal cancer.
The number of lymph node found from the surgical specimen
The postoperative hospital stay is defined as the number of date from the first day after operation to discharge.
This section is assessed using a self-rating scale "International prostate symptom score" (IPSS).

secondary_outcome.measure: Self reported sexual function for male patients
secondary_outcome.description: This section is assessed using a self-rating scale "International Index of Erectile Function" (IIEF-5).

secondary_outcome.measure: Self reported sexual function for female patients
secondary_outcome.description: This section is assessed using a self-rating scale "Female Sexual Function Index" (FSFI).

intervention.description: Arm I: Robot-assisted resection using da vinci system.
